Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Does a transition in nitrogen fixation strategy explain the latitudinal distribution of nitrogen-fixing trees?
Award.AbstractNarration:
Nitrogen (N) is a necessary nutrient for plant growth. Although the atmosphere mainly consists of nitrogen gas (N2), this form of N is extremely stable. Most plants can't directly access N2 and their rate of growth is limited by the presence of available N in the soil. Therefore, some species of trees have evolved a symbiosis with a special class of bacteria that fix atmospheric N2 and convert it into a plant available form. These N-fixing trees have abundant access to N, but there is a cost to this symbiotic association: these trees provide carbon to bacteria and therefore sacrifice some of their own growth to maintain the symbiosis. As a result, N-fixing trees comprise only a small proportion of tree species on earth. In theory, N fixation is only advantageous in ecosystems that have very limited amounts of N in the soil. N-limited forests tend to be more common at high latitudes than at lower latitudes (the tropics and subtropics), but curiously, N-fixing trees are actually most common at lower latitudes. In fact, N-fixing trees are ten times less abundant at higher latitudes than at lower latitudes. Why is this the case? This proposal will test a potential explanation. The "differential regulation hypothesis" states that variation in the degree to which N-fixing trees regulate N fixation can explain the pattern. N-fixing trees that rapidly adjust N-fixation to meet N demand should be more abundant, as is the case in lower-latitude forests. In contrast, species that cannot regulate N-fixation should be less abundant, as observed in higher-latitude forests. This project will measure the extent to which the regulation of N-fixation actually varies across latitudes, as well as the metabolic costs of regulating N-fixation and the relationship of these costs to temperature. The results will provide a long sought after explanation for the distribution of N-fixing trees on earth, which is an essential component of the growth of forests worldwide.

The project will involve a field experiment in forests at different latitudes as well as two greenhouse experiments. The field experiment will fertilize forests with labeled N to vary the degree of N limitation and measure the regulation of N fixation in the field. The experimental locations are Oregon (with Alnus rubra), New York (with Robinia pseudoacacia), and Hawaii (with Morella faya, Casuarina equisetifolia, Acacia koa, and Sophora chrysophylla) and span the latitudinal threshold for N-fixing tree abundance (35Â° N). There are two major types of N fixing symbioses (actinorhizal and rhizobial) and the field sites were chosen to capture both. The greenhouse experiments will test a larger number of species and involve more highly controlled conditions. The greenhouse experiments will also evaluate how quickly plants can regulate N fixation. The experiments and laboratory analyses will involve participation of Title 1 high school students as well as undergraduate and graduate students in New York, California and Oregon.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual merit:

 

This project studied symbiotic nitrogen-fixing trees, which are tree species that can form root structures (?nodules?) to house specialized bacteria that fix nitrogen. ?Nitrogen fixation? turns nitrogen gas (which is 78% of air) into a form that plants can use. The newly fixed nitrogen is used by the plants and bacteria to make protein and other useful things, but eventually it gets back into soils, where it can have lots of consequences. It can help plants grow (which takes carbon dioxide out of the atmosphere, helping us with climate change), but it can also pollute the air (causing smog via nitric oxide and climate change via nitrous oxide) and water (causing dead zones and poor water quality). Whether the additional nitrogen causes more plant growth or more pollution depends on how much the symbioses adjust nitrogen fixation. If nitrogen-fixing symbioses stop fixing nitrogen when there is plenty of nitrogen already available in the soil (a ?facultative? strategy), they cause plants to grow more. On the other hand, if they continue to fix nitrogen even when there?s plenty in the soil (an ?obligate? strategy if they keep fixing at the same rate or an ?incomplete? strategy if they turn fixation down but not off), they cause more pollution.

Which strategy these symbioses use could also help explain a curious pattern in ecology: Nitrogen-fixing trees are ten times more common in tropical forests than in temperate and boreal forests in the Americas, even though the soil conditions are more favorable for them in temperate and boreal forests. Mathematical modeling says that this curious ecological pattern could be explained by the ?differential regulation hypothesis,? i.e., if tropical nitrogen-fixing trees use a facultative strategy but temperate nitrogen-fixing trees use an obligate one.

The main goal of this project was to learn whether different types of symbiotic nitrogen-fixing trees were facultative, obligate, or incomplete. We studied two common temperate nitrogen-fixing trees (black locust and red alder) and four common tropical nitrogen-fixing trees in field sites in New York, Oregon, and Hawaii. We studied these six species and seven additional species in greenhouse experiments. We set up both the field and greenhouse experiments to provide a range of nitrogen available in the soil, from very little to more than enough. We then measured growth, nitrogen fixation, and other things.

Surprisingly, we found that all the symbioses we studied in the field were either obligate or incomplete: they continued to fix nitrogen even when there was plenty of nitrogen in the soil. Our preliminary greenhouse findings support the field findings, though we?re still waiting for some data (thanks, COVID-19). Our results mean that (1) the differential regulation hypothesis does not explain why symbiotic nitrogen-fixing trees are so common in the tropical forests in the Americas, and that (2) even if nitrogen-fixing trees initially help forests grow and store carbon, they will also cause air pollution and water pollution.

In addition to this main finding, we made many other discoveries during this project. For example, we measured how long it takes for nitrogen-fixing trees to adjust fixation: weeks. As another example, for the four tree species we studied, the optimal temperature for nitrogen fixation was 4-11?C higher than in the equation currently used in global models. The equation in these global models comes from free-living bacteria rather than the symbioses they are modeling, so our findings are the best available data.

 

Broader impacts:

 

This project provided student research opportunities, broadened participation in ecology, helps understand global climate change, and helps guide reforestation. One postdoc, 7 technicians, 8 PhD students, 4 Masters students, 1 post-baccalaureate student, and 17 undergraduates worked in the project. These students represent a diverse team, including 12 BIPOC scientists, at least 3 LGBTQIA+ scientists, and at least 2 first generation college students; 80% of the team was female. A diverse group of students in two courses also conducted projects in the New York field site. Therefore, our work increased the representation of underrepresented groups in ecology.

Our finding that nitrogen-fixing symbioses fix nitrogen when they do not need it has multiple consequences for society. On the subject of climate change: we are currently putting this finding into one of the global models used in the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) reports. The consequences for carbon storage and nitrous oxide will influence future projections of climate change. On the subject of reforestation: the idea that planting trees can help with climate change has made headlines over the past year. Before our work, it was commonly thought that nitrogen-fixing trees would be good species to plant because they would provide more nitrogen to the forest and stimulate carbon storage. Our finding that nitrogen-fixing trees can exacerbate climate change in certain circumstances will help guide decisions about which trees to plant.
